entries.name: Entnagle
entries: Some weapons, particularly those with lengths of rope or chains, are designed to wrap around a foe's weapon or limbs.

A creature can use an attack with such a weapon to entangle the target's weapon or limbs. The attacker makes an attack roll contested by the target's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. The target has advantage on its ability check if it is larger than the attacking creature, or disadvantage if it is smaller. If the attacker wins the contest, the attack causes no damage or other ill effect, but becomes entangled by the attacker.

An entangled creature has disadvantage on attack rolls until the attacker ends the entanglement with a bonus action; the attacker drops their weapon or the attacker is {@condition incapacitated}; forced movement causes the attacker and target apart beyond the reach of the weapon; or the target uses its action to escape (as though {@condition grappled}). While entangled, neither the attacker nor the target can move apart beyond the reach of the weapon.
While the attacker is entangling the target's weapon, it has advantage on subsequent attempts to disarm the target (see DMG p. 271)

entries.name: Role
entries: An artificer takes on the role of a magical item expert, combining much of the flexibility of a wizard with the critical eye of a rogue, and provide access to magical effects that the rest of the party would not normally have. The artificer is often able to provide solutions for situations where either brute strength is not enough or the available spells are not appropriate to the task at hand. While they are not incredibly suited for front-line combat, given the proper time to prepare, an artificer's infusions can easily turn the rest of the party into a tailor-made fighting force against their chosen foe.

entries.name: Crafting an Artificer
entries: An artificer is the preeminent engineer of magical goods and supplies. Consider what drives your artificer to study and experiment. Is if for fame? For the sake of their knowledge? Proof of concept? Is it under the belief they can make a difference? Or is it really about money?

Think about what your artificer is more focused on. In addition to their main interest a within creation, there will be latitude for most to do other things, but the different schools are better at a certain abilities.

variantrule.name: Arcane Schema
entries: A schema differs from a spell in that a schema doesn't pull the magic to create the effect - it the understanding needed to infuse the power of that Schema into an item but not to cast the spell itself. Therefore, you cannot cast the spell directly (but are able to create scrolls or wands with the spell's ability imbued within it). Some Schema's knowledge also allows you to research and create Formulae that have the prerequisite spell as a requirement for creation.

Schemas are not the same as a warlock's, a cleric, sorcerer or even a wizard's magic - being neither arcane or divine in nature, but are those spell's underlying pattern, the most basic form of the magic's effect. Effectively its a reverse engineering of a spell/enchantment into a workable Schema, this is the THEORY of the magic and its patterns, and isn't spell in the strictess of terms. Again, The schema isn't a spell - and only the most skilled of those skilled in Arcane can build a workable spell from a schema. (Doing so doesn't remove or destroy the schema.)

entries: A Spell with the reversible tag has two forms which are availible to chose from when prepared. While the spell is one spell, it will have at least two (often polar opposite) effects, if the spell is chosen as a prepared spells for that day, which version(effect) of the spell must be stated in advance. If the spell is considered as always prepared both version can be called upon. This harkens back to 1st Edition AD&D. In which you could cast Cure or Cause wounds.

subclassFeatures.name: Phantom Blade
entries: Some rogues choose to focus their training on ways to blend magical talent with their rogue talents. Over time, this training gave way to a group of rogues that learned how to create and use a personal extradimensional space to support their talents. At first, this space was used to stash useful and important items from prying eyes and wandering hands. As these rogues developed greater and more fine-tuned ability to manipulate this space, a new form of attack took shape. Because of the peculiar and distinctive nature of this attack, these rogues came to be known as phantom blades.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} for the general rules of spellcasting and chapter 11 for the {@filter warlock spell list|spells|class=warlock}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn three cantrips: {@spell phantom stash|phtm}, {@spell phantom recall|phtm} and {@spell phantom blade|phtm} at 3rd level.
At 7th level, 11th, and 15th level you gain an additional cantrip.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Phantom Blade table shows how many spell slots you have. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your Phantom Blade spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest. For example, when you are 7th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell {@spell witch bolt|PhB}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know one 1st-level warlock spell of your choice. The Spells Known column of the Phantom Blade Spellcasting table shows when you learn more warlock spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be a conjuration or enchantment spell of your choice and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 7th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of the warlock spells you know with another spell of your choice from the warlock spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be a conjuration or enchantment.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells, so you use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when selling the saving throw DC for a warlock spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Phantom Zone
entries: At 3rd level, you develop connection to an extra dimensional pocket that only you can access. This pocket space is separate from your inventory and can contain 2 lbs or 8 cubic feet of content. The contents do not count against your encumbrance. If the character dies, their pocket dimension collapses and its contents are lost to Astral Space.
This space grows an additional 1 lb. per level, and a larger container at 5th (16 ft.Â³), 11th(27 ft.Â³) and 42 ft.Â³ cubic feet at 17th level.

entries.name: Phantom Augmentations
entries: You develop augmentations which agument your phantasmal space abilities. At 4th level, you gain a phantasmal augmentation of your choice. Your augmentations options are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain phantom blade levels, you gain additional agumentations of your choice, as shown in the Augmentations Known column of the Phantom Blade table.

entries.name: Magical Ambush
entries: At 9th level, at the end of your round, if you hit a creature with your phantom blade ability, you can choose to manifest a ghostly image of the weapon you used to make the attack. This manifested blade must appear adjacent to the creature you hit. If your attack hit multiple creatures, you choose which square adjacent of one of those creatures your manifested blade appears. The manifest blade counts an ally using the help action and so grants advantage to attacks against its chosen creature. They only last until the end of your next turn.
{@monster Manifest Blade|phtm}

It uses your saves and if your manifested blade is subjected to an effect that allows a Dexterity save for half damage, it instead takes no damage on a successful save. If an enemy would provoke an opportunity attack from your manifested blade, you can use your reaction to direct it to attack that enemy. Using this ability does not require any additional action, but it does occupy your concentration while active. If you attempt to use this ability while it is already active, all currently manifested blades vanish before any new manifested blades appear.

entries.name: Opportunistic Reaction
entries: At 13th level, you gain the ability to build off even small advantages, if you have advantage on a creature that exposes itself to an Attack of Opportunity from you, if the weapon allows for such, you may also apply sneak damage. At 13th level, your Manifest Blade gain the ability to build off even small advantages, if a creature within range of the Manifest Blade moves out of its threaten space and evokes an attack of opportunity - you no long need to use your reaction for the Manifest Blade to make its attack - it does so separately. The Manifest blade deals sneak attack damage on a successful strike. While manifested, the blades now (Rogue's choice) Either:

items: {@b Parry}: dancing about they impose disadvantage on the creature's next attack, or
{@b Distract}: grant advantage on the next attack against the creature. (It still remains an ally for the purposes of Rogue sneak attack or pack tactics.

entries.name: Phantom Ambush
entries: At 17th level, your manifest blade ability improves. If your attack hits multiple creatures, you can now manifest a ghostly image of your weapon adjacent to each of them. If any enemy provokes an opportunity attack from a manifested blade, you can use your reaction your attack of opportunity against an enemy that leaves a space your weapon threatens.

Its magic is something that you can use to co-opt and corrupt the efforts of others in situations. See {@book chapter 10|PHB|10} of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting and below for the {@filter dirge spell list|spells|class=dirge|source=reddit_UA}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the Dirdge spell list. You learn additional Dirge cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the {@filter dirge spell list|spells|class=dirge|source=reddit_UA}.

entries.name: Spell Points
entries: The table above tells how many spell points you have to cast your spells. To cast one of these spells. you must expend one point per level of the Spell Slot of the spell you wish to cast. You regain half of all your expended spell slots when you finish a short rest, and all them on a long rest.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Dirge spells. Your magic comes from the ability to warp reality and force patterns, it is in part divine, and in part aberrant ability of your force of will bringing the world into more chaos. Use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a dirge spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any bard spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an book focus (found in chapter 5) as a spellcasting focus for your dirge spells.

entries.name: Learning Spells of 1st Level and Higher
entries: Each time you gain a dirge level, you can add one dirge spells of your choice to your spellbook. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots, as shown on the {@filter dirge spell list|spells|class=dirge|source=reddit_UA} table. On your adventures, you might find other spells that you can add to your spellbook (see "Your Spellbook").

entries.name: Your Spellbook
entries: The spells that you add to your spellbook as you gain levels reflect the arcane research you conduct on your own, as well as intellectual breakthroughs you have had about the nature of the multiverse. You might find other spells during your adventures. You could discover a spell recorded on a scroll in an evil creature's library, for example, or in a dusty tome in an ancient library.
A spellbook doesn't contain cantrips.

entries.name: Copying a Spell into the Book
entries: When you find a spell of 1st level or higher that is on your spell list, you can add it to your spellbook if it is of a spell level you can prepare and if you can spare the time to decipher and copy it.

Copying a spell into your spellbook involves reproducing the basic form of the spell, then deciphering the unique system of notation used by the spellcaster who wrote it. You must practice the spell until you understand the sounds or gestures required, then transcribe it into your spellbook using your own notation.

For each level of the spell, the process takes 2 hours and costs 50 gp. The cost represents material components you expend as you experiment with the spell to master it, as well as the fine inks you need to record it. Once you have spent this time and money, you can prepare the spell just like your other spells.

A spell on scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When you copy a spell from a spell scroll, you must succeed on an Intelligence (Arcana) check with a DC equal to 10 + the spell's level. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.

entries.name: Replacing the Book
entries: You can copy a spell from your own spellbook into another book—for example, if you want to make a backup copy of your spellbook. This is just like copying a new spell into your spellbook, but faster and easier, since you understand your own notation and already know how to cast the spell. You need spend only 1 hour and 10 gp for each level of the copied spell.

If you lose your spellbook, you can use the same procedure to transcribe the spells that you have prepared into a new spellbook. Filling out the remainder of your spellbook requires you to find new spells to do so, as normal. For this reason, many casters keep backup spellbooks in a safe place.

entries.name: The Book's Appearance
entries: Your book is a unique compilation of spells, poems, music notation, and stains, with its own decorative flourishes and margin notes. It might be a plain, functional leather volume that you received as a gift from your master, a finely bound gilt-edged tome you found in an ancient library, or even a loose collection of notes scrounged together after you lost your previous spellbook in a mishap.

classFeatures.name: Enervate
entries: You discourage others through biting words, rebukes, and statistical probabilities of their failure and eventual death at a loved one's hands.

To do so, you use a reaction to choose one creature other than yourself within 60 feet of you who can hear YOU. That creature rolls your Enervation die, a 1d6 at 1st level, and "subtracts" the number rolled to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw it makes. You can choose to use this feature after the creature makes its roll, but before the DM determines whether the attack roll or ability check succeeds or fails, or before the creature does damage. If the creature can't hear, or doesn't speak your language the enervation fails. Creatures that are immune to Charm, or are Constructs are immune.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain any expended uses when you finish a long rest.
Your Enervation die changes when you reach certain levels in this class; at 5th level (d8), at 10th level (d10), and finally at 15th level (2d6).

classFeatures.name: Expertise/Master of None
entries: Choose three of your skills proficiencies. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that the chosen proficiencies. HOWEVER; After a long rest you temporarily lose any proficiency bonus in one skill you have (had) expertise until your next long rest (determined randomly).
You gain half of your proficiency bonus (or Your Intelligence Ability Modifier - whichever is greater) on all Tools, Kits, and Charisma-based checks with which you are non-proficient.
At 10th level, you can choose another two skill proficiencies to gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Familiar
entries: At 2nd level you will acquire a familiar/animal companion.

This isn't a {@italic magical} familiar, if lost/killed it cannot be resummoned. It gains +2 HP with each level the Dirge obtains while with that familar.  If the familiar dies unlike a Ranger animal companions or wizard/warlock familars, you don't resummon it during a ritual long rest. No, you have to go find another one. You must buy/steal or coax it into your service if you need to replace it. Once the type of creature is chosen it is the one type that grants you those benefits alone. If you have a goat and then after its tragic (but expected) death, you cannot switch to a cat. You are stuck with a goat (or whatever).
Your familiar gains HP are also

classFeatures.name: Emotionally Abusive
entries: You may add your Intelligence Modifier to any Psychic damage source you deal.

classFeatures.name: Meh
entries: Starting at 4th level, you unlock similar powers similar to Warlock's Invocations called {@filter Mehs|optionalfeatures|source=reddit_UA} these are abilities, powers, or enhancements .

You may additionally choose from the following invocations from Warlocks: {@optfeature Bewitching Whispers}, {@optfeature Chains of Carceri}, {@optfeature Dreadful Word}, {@optfeature Eyes of the Run Keeper}, {@optfeature Fiendish Vigor}, {@optfeature Mask of Many Faces}, {@optfeature Mire the Mind}, {@optfeature Misty Visions}, {@optfeature Witch Sight}.

classFeatures.name: Tough Love
entries: At 3rd level, you use a bonus action to use your biting tongue to compel a target creature within 60 ft. to redouble their efforts and do better. It is not nice, and its very pointed, but the target receives an enervation die or your Charisma Modifier to enhance an Attack roll To Hit, for Damage, Saves, Ability and Skill checks.

The Target Takes an enervation die of Psychic Damage to their Max HP until the die is used (after which the damage may be healed normally). Once given the recipient has 1 minute to use this die before or after they make a roll, but always before the DM determines whether the attack roll or ability is successful.

classFeatures.name: Divine Filler
entries: At 3rd level, You really receive nothing from this.

But that's reality. However, at this seemingly arbitrary point in your development, you must choose a path of philosophy and develop toward such. You don't gain anything, but later on, you'll have to keep to your decision you make today...

items: {@bold Epistemological} - all knowledge is accepted as possibly untrue or unable to be known. Additionally, morality is seen as subjective or false.

{@bold Existential} - life has no intrinsic meaning or value. With respect to the universe, existential nihilism posits that a single human or even the entire human species is insignificant, without purpose and unlikely to change in the totality of existence.

{@bold Mereologic} - is the position that objects with proper parts do not exist (not only objects in space but also objects existing in time do not have any temporal parts), and only basic building blocks without parts exist, and thus the world we see and experience full of objects with parts is a product of human misrepresentation (i.e., if we could see clearly, we would not perceive compositive objects).

classFeatures.name: Placebo
entries: At 3rd Level you gain the ability as an full round to use a placebo. Taking Water or wine, or whatever - you roll a performance check (action)

Upon administering the Placebo to a single creature (bonus action), the creature(s) makes a Wisdom save with disadvantage against your performance roll as the DC, if they fail they get better (2d4 temporary hit points), and 1 real hp. The creature and you must be able to understand each other for this to happen.
You may do this any number of times, sadly until a creature successfully saves against your Placebo.
Once a creature saves, That creature cannot benefit from your placebo, ever, and you may not use another placebo until a day has passed.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Disruptive Banter
entries: At 5th level, you gain the ability to use your Enervation to disrupt a single spell or mind-influencing effect. As an action, you can start a {skill performance} that lasts up to a minute. During that time, you and any allied creatures within 30 feet of you have advantage on saving throws against being frightened or charmed. And nonfriendly creatures are at disadvantage for such.

A creature must share a language and be able to hear you to be affected. The performance ends early if you are incapacitated or silenced or if you voluntarily end it (no action required). Hostile Creatures attempting to maintain concentration must make a save each against your spell DC. If their concentration is broken, they take d6 psychic damage as a backlash.

classFeatures.name: Enervate (d8)
entries: Your Enervation die changes to (d8).

classFeatures.name: Channel snort "Divinity"
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to channel so called {@bold divine} energy directly once per every long rest from your angst over the nature and paradox of divinity, using that energy to fuel magical effects. You must then finish a long rest to use your Channel Divinity again. Some Channel Divinity effects require saving throws.
When you use such an effect from this class, the DC equals your Dirge spell save DC.

Beginning at 6th level, you can use your Channel Divinity twice between rests, and beginning at 18th level, you can use it three times between rests. When you finish a short or long rest, you regain your expended uses.

entries.name: Channel: Divinity
entries: As an reaction, you speak to a creature with that can hear and understand your language within 30 ft. has disadvantage imposed upon its roll.

classFeatures.name: Troll's Regeneration
entries: Beginning when you reach 6th level, you regain all of your expended uses of Enervation when you finish a short or long rest.

classFeatures.name: Orator
entries: At 7th level, you gain the ability to use {@spell Tongues} (as the spell - but without spell components costs) once per rest. You regain the use of this when you finish a short or long rest.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeatures.name: Enervate (d10)
entries: At 9th level, your Enervation die changes to (d10).

classFeatures.name: Expertise/Master of None (2)
entries: At 10th level, you can choose another two skill proficiencies, double the proficiency bonus for these skills, however you now lose proficiency with two skills at random per long rest.

classFeatures.name: Philosophical Feature

classFeatures.name: Dark Thoughts
entries: Beginning at 10th level, your angst hones your mental fortitude. You have resistance to psychic damage, and whenever a creature deals psychic damage to you, as a reaction that creature takes half that damage. Attempts to gain insight into you are at disadvantage; you turn the mind-affecting magic of your enemies against them and you are immune to being charmed. When another creature attempts to charm you, you can use your reaction to attempt to turn the charm back on that creature, in addition that creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or be frightened by you for 1 minute.

classFeatures.name: Shared Delusion
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can plunge a creature into an illusory realm. As an action, choose a creature that you can see within 60 feet of you. It must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it is charmed or frightened by you (your choice made before their save) for 1 minute or until your concentration is broken (as if you are concentrating on a spell). This effect ends early if the creature takes any damage. Until this illusion ends, the creature thinks it is lost in a dark diasporic version of reality, the appearance of which you choose. The creature can see and hear only itself, you, and the illusion - the experience (if frightening) deals d8 psychic damage each round when the effect is ended they are frightened of you. If the effect was charming, they gain the belief they are healed and fully restored as if a long rest - they are not, and they'll think they are casting spells, using abilities they cannot use.
{@i You must finish a long rest before you can use this feature again.}

classFeatures.name: Enervate (d12)
entries: At 15th level, your Enervation die changes to (1d12).

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement

subclassFeatures.name: Pointless Persuit
entries: Starting at 14th level, you instill within a creature the certainty that its current path is fruitless and to abandon the effort. As an action, choose a creature that you can see within 20 feet of you. It must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it is effectively charmed by you. Whatever the DM holds as its current goal/action it abandons. (ie A Creature in a battle might stop and leave combat; a person eating will stop). This effect lasts up to 1 hour. If a new reason to engage in that same action comes up again, that creature can re-engage. In the example of the combat, if another creature attacks it while it is attempting to leave combat, it gets to save again. A creature that saves cannot be the subject of this ability again for a day.
{@i You must finish a short or long rest before you can use this feature again.}

subclassFeatures.name: Divine Filler
entries: Choose one of the following:

entries.name: Channel Apathy: Undead
entries: You get it. Being Alive sucks and being undead isn't an improvement. When you channel your Apathy, all undead creatures that can hear or see you within 30 feet must make a Wisdom saving throw. If the creature fails its saving throw, it is apathetic for 1 minute or until it takes damage from you. An apathetic creature will disengage and move at half rate back to its resting place. It will ignore any creature not trying to attack it (treat as if invisible).
{@i For example, they managed to pick the lock, but also break their thieve's tools ruining the lock, or makes the attack against a creature, but drops their weapon as they fall prone before it.

entries.name: Channel Apathy: Death
entries: The Afterlife, if it exists, is likely eternal suffering. This joker in front of you would only add to the misery of those miserable souls. Meh, call yourself sentimental for that pet you watched die that time. your pet doesn't deserve this A-Hole's whining filling the afterworld(s).

You channel your power to bring a creature that had died up to a minute ago, back to life with 1 hp. They and you have resistance to healing for 1 day, and you have disadvantage on all Social checks against that creature in the future.

entries.name: Channel Apathy: Ignore
entries: {@i Requires Concentration}

When you channel Apathy, you become, effectively, invisible for up to 1 hour.  Unlike the spell, this is a enchantment, creatures of intelligence 5 or greater are magically presuaded to not want to see, hear or interact with you.  They wish to ignore you if possible. Furthermore you create a bubble with a 30 ft. radius centered on you. All perception or insight rolls inside the affected area are at disadvantage.

You may speak and limitedly take action - thou any attack on a creature will remove that creature's from enchantment's effect.  All others must make an intelligence save if your interactions would violate their moral or professional code.  A guardsman being potentially aware of you stealing something would get a save. A person wanting or needing to get through a door you are standing infront of would trigger a saving throw check. Perhaps eating food off a nobleman's or starving peasant's plate would prompt either to choose to not ignore you and thus trigger a save.

A person free of the enchantment must make a persuasion check against either the spell's DC to get everyone in the area to take notice, or may attempt to focus on a single person as an action to force that person to attempt to no longer ignore the Dirge. (prompting a saving throw).
Once a creature has successfully saved they see you (the Dirge) and cannot be effected by another Ignore channel for a day, and gain advantage on all future attempts to force them to ignore.
at each subsquent dirge level you may exchange your current channel ability for a different one.

subclassFeatures.name: Yeah... Whatever
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when making a saving throw against an ability that deals Psychic damage or imposes the Charm, Frightened, or condition. You may choose to take a level of exhaustion to automatically succeed provided the Charmed, or Frighted condition effect have not yet been applied.

subclassFeatures.name: Life?... meh.
entries: The archetypal Champion focuses on the development of raw physical power honed to deadly perfection. Those who model themselves on this archetype combine rigorous training with physical excellence to deal devastating blows.

entries.name: Improved Critical
entries: Beginning when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

entries: You get nothing. That's the way that goes - you have to make the choice and see what comes from your choices. Later on.

subclassFeatures.name: Divine Filler
entries: Choose one of the following:

entries.name: Channel Dysfunction: Pauli Effect
entries: Things break down, don't work, more so around you. When you channel all other creatures within 30 ft. of you immediately lose attunement to their magical item(s).

entries.name: Channel Dysfunction: Juxtaposition
entries: Things never make sense, but then again they shouldn't obviously we're not here for {@i a reason} we're just here, wherever that is. As either a bonus action or a reaction you may channel this power, make a ranged to hit roll for a creature or object that you can see or know its absolute position (are very familiar with) within 100 ft. You and that target change places. If the creature is hostile, it gets a Dexterity Save to avoid being shifted, and instead, you appear in its square crowding it.

entries.name: Channel Dysfunction: Leech
entries: {@i Requires Concentration}

You not only suck the fun out events, you suck the very luck from the room as well. When you channel this you create a 20'ft radius aura. All creatures except you in the radius have a -d4 for all their Ability, Skill, and initative checks. Damage amounts are also reduced by 1. The effect last for 1 minute or until concentration is broken.
at each subsquent dirge level you may exchange your current channel ability for a different one.

The Pauli effect is a term referring to the apparently mysterious, anecdotal failure of technical equipment in the presence of Austrian theoretical physicist Wolfgang Pauli. The term was coined using his name after numerous instances in which demonstrations involving equipment suffered technical problems only when he was present

subclassFeatures.name: Entrophic Ward
entries: Beginning at 10th level, you learn to magically ward yourself against attack and to turn an enemy's failed strike into good luck for yourself, When a creature makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on that roll. If the attack misses you, before the end of your text turn your next attack roll against that creature has advantage. On a critical fail against you, you regain a use of enervation.
{@i You may use this feature (Int Modifier) times every short or long rest.}

subclassFeatures.name: Solipsism
entries: Starting at 14th level, as an action you create an extra-natural force. The Dirge and whomever he informs of his intent must make a Wisdom save against the Dirge's Charisma ability score as the DC. On a successful save all those that succeeded experience the Solipsism as real. Unlike true illusions, the image created by this spell does more than just duplicate reality. The image formed is real for those who believe in it. The illusion has all the normal properties that its form and function allow. Thus, a solipsistic bridge spanning a chasm could be crossed by the dirge and those who believed. All others would see the priest apparently walking out onto nothingness. A Solipsism of a barrier would block a dragon's breath weapon. Creatures are not affected (the dragon) by the Solipsism would be able to move through the object as if doesn't exist (because, to them - it does not).
Solipsism can create only illusions that are external to the Dirge. Thus, the Dirge cannot create an illusion that he is the size of a giant, is unwounded, or has sprouted wings

entries.name: Improved Critical
entries: Beginning when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, your weapon attacks score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

Troubor, Bard, Minstrel, Gleeman, and Loremaster. All are names that talk about those spirits of adventure, whose use music,poetry, and dance bring merriment and delight. They distract and delude their audience bringing hope to hopeless and respite to those souls weary from the fight.
But, there is a darker side.

The Anti-Bard. The Dirge. Nilhilism embodied. Part Bard, Part Warlock, Part Cleric - even though they themselves do not believe in god(s) - or at the very least they don't believe there is any reason for them to interact with the Mortal Realms and that even if gods did their interdictions would only make things complicated on a level that no mortal could untangle thus necessitating the gods further interceded to solve the mess they already created, causeing...
Well, you get it.

Unlike Warlocks, the Dirges haven't formed an alliance with a lower realm, the Greater Fey, certainly not the elder gods or the like. But like Warlocks the class has Invocation like abilities called "Mehs" which are gained as they level so that very few Dirges will really ever appear to have similar powers.
While Bards do have specific colleges, Dirges will fixate upon specific aspects of their nihilistic philosophy.
They delight in confounding the faithful, existential crisses, and shattering the veil of the mass delussion of popular held possitions.
In short... they're 'that guy' (or gal).
ie. Assholes.
These are the dark harbingers, the Luckeaters, Mirthless, the Joyless ones,... the Dark Souls.
Dirges recite histories, statistics and use their companions and opponent's insecurities as whetstones upon which they hone their abilities.
They disprove the saying "Sticks and Stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me."

tools: any one type of artisan's tool, in which you gain expertise.

default: one set of tools with which you are proficient

classFeatures.name: Good Plain Folk
entries: You are proficient in the use of artisan's tools as weapons, and add your expertise bonus when attacking with them. The deal 1d4 of whatever damage type is appropriate for the tool.
All of your ability scores are 10, and cannot be naturally increased. You are nothing special.

classFeatures.name: Callow Youth
entries: And yet you know you're destined for greatness! You can give yourself advantage on any d20 roll by gritting your teeth and looking danger in the eye. You regain the use of this ability when you finish a short or long rest.

classFeatures.name: The Darnedest Thing
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can survive the adventuring life through sheer coincidence. When you would be killed or reduced to 0 hp, you may tell the story (10 seconds or less) of how the darnedest thing happened that completely prevented the effect. You regain the use of this ability when you finish a long rest.

classFeatures.name: Sidekick
entries: You're surrournded by badasses, why not be like them!? When you finish a long rest, pick an ally you can see. Choose one piece of equipment, one skill, and one saving throw with which that ally is proficient. You gain those proficiencies until you choose a new ally or you spend more than 3 days without spending time with the chosen ally.

classFeatures.name: Questgiver
entries: At 3rd level, whenever you finish a short or long rest, a bright yellow exclamation mark appears above your head. Choose up to three allies within 10 feet, and give them each one of the following quests:

entries.name: Main Plot Quest

classFeatures.name: Infusions
entries: You gain the ability to create Infusions. Infusions are neither arcane nor divine; they are drawn from the complex Magical Schemas and then infused into the forms listed below. They function just like spells and follow all the rules for spells. For example, an infusion can be dispelled, it will not function in an antimagic area, and an artificer must make a Concentration check if injured while attempting to imbue/place an infusion (failure means the infusion is stopped and must be restarted).

As an Artificer, you use Schemas (see below) in combination with your known Infusion Formulae (See Below) from the list formulae you have learned/created/or discovered. Like spell casters, you automatically gain Infusions as you progress. Like Wizards, it is possible for you to learn new infusions and Schemas. These might include ancient infusions you find in the ruins of Xen'drik or secret infusions known only to the members of certain guilds or organizations.

Infusions have longer casting times and you will need to plan ahead as several infusions will take hours (at times even weeks) to cast, and as such you cast them from your books - without them... you are nearly powerless.

entries.name: Arcane Schema
entries: You are able to learn a spell's schemas that you keep in your schema book. A schema differs from a spell in that a schema doesn't pull the magic to create the effect - it the understanding needed to infuse the power of that Schema into an item but not to cast the spell itself. Therefore, you cannot cast the spell directly (but are able to create scrolls or wands with the spell's ability imbued within it). Some Schema's knowledge also allows you to research and create Formulae that have the prerequisite spell as a requirement for creation.

As with Infusions, schemas are not the same as a warlock's, a cleric, sorcerer or even a wizard's magic - being neither arcane or divine in nature, but are those spell's underlying pattern, the most basic form of the magic's effect. Any other class would not be able to pick up the book and reverse engineer the spell schema into a workable spell. (DM's Fiat obviously overrides that).

You can also copy the addition spells into your schema book by examining a scroll, a spell book, schema book (This does not use up the book). Artificer's automatically know how to use any of their known spells as schemas and does not need to keep schema of the spell in their schema book -- for spells gained from multi-classing, however, this does not go both ways. They may not use Spell Schema's they've learned as spells and cast them through the use of spell slots.

Additionally, Whenever another creature casts a spell (and is within your schema level range), as a reaction you can make an Arcane (Intelligence) check against the caster's spell DC. If successful you remember the details of the spell and can add it to your schema book. You can only hold onto one spell until you've copied it, and you are must maintain concentration to hold the spell schema in memory until the copying is completed. Copying Schemas costs 20gp and 1 hour per spell slot (though some infusions may reduce that time).

When starting off as an Artificer you start with (Intelligence ability modifier (Minimum 1)) spell slot levels of schemas in your schema book. Those schemas must be of a level no greater than your Proficiency bonus (Cantrips count as level 1 spell slot.)

entries.name: Infusion Formulae
entries: Formulae are essentially the pattern and plan of the infusion for the Artificer. A formulae often requires specific schemas and materials which are either used up, may be recovered, or are now forever part of the object being infused.

As a general rule, if the DM allows for Artificers to develop/research additional Formulae it is suggested to use the DMG guidance for magic item creation with the value of 1,000gp cost per infusion point.

entries.name: Infusion Points
entries: You are limited to certain amount of mystical energy you draw upon each day. This is referred to as your Infusion points. You maximum Infusion points are equal to the Points listed in the table above for your level. At the dawn of each day your used infusion points are restored.Â¹ In general, Infusions maintain themselves for 24 hours, or until the Dawn of the next day. You may never have unexpended Infusion Points that exceeds the Maximum Infusions points for your level plus your Intelligence modifier.

Creating an Infusion costs a number of Infusion Points, as noted in the Infusion's description, and also costs materials (also noted in the Infusion's Descriptions). When an item is under the effect of an Infusion, that item is considered magical for the purposes of Detect Magic, Identify and Dispel Magic, but unless the infusion states otherwise, NOT for purposes of overcoming damage resistances or immunities. The total number of Infusion Points invested in a single item or Automaton cannot exceed the lowests caster's Infusion Maximum. [This is a clarification for when multiple Artificers are working together on a single item]

entries: Artificers do not obtain spell slots, for purposes of spell descriptions and multiclassing, your Artificer levels are full caster levels, but again you gain no spell slots while advancing in Artificer.
Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for you artificer spells. You use your Intelligence modifier whenever an Infusion or spell refers to your spellcasting ability.

entries.name: Arcane Spellcasting
entries: At 1st level you can cast any spell you know. (Spells and Schemas are different things) Doing so uses infusion points equal to twice the spell slot used, you may not use a higher spell slot then the highest spell level you can learn.
You also gain {@b Overcharge} (as per the 9th level ability)

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: The Artificer  table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of spells that are available for you to cast. To do so, choose a number of wizard spells from your spellbook equal to your Intelligence modifier + your wizard level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots.

For example, if you're a 3rd-level wizard, you have four 1st-level and two 2nd-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st or 2nd level, in any combination, chosen from your spellbook. If you prepare the 1st-level spell {@spell magic missile}, you can cast it using a 1st-level or a 2nd-level slot. Casting the spell doesn't remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of wizard spells requires time spent studying your spellbook and memorizing the incantations and gestures you must make to cast the spell: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Ritual Spellcasting:
entries: You can cast any spell you know as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag. Doing so uses 1 infusion point regardless of its level.

entries.name: Arcane Adaptability:
entries: When you learn a spell you may instead learn a variant of that spell (chosen upon leveling up), if the spell does a damage type, you may cast a variant of the spell which does another form of damage or gives another equal condition (ie - deaf and silenced; converted to restrained and grappled) or requires a different Save (Dex vs Wis). You may develop a variant version of 1 spell at every even level taken in the Artificer class.

entries: At 3rd level, you craft an implement. The implement costs 500gp and takes 2 weeks to build. This implement can be an orb, a Medallion, a staff, a rod, a Libram, or a wand. Your implement grants certain benefits to spells cast through it, depending on the type of implement you've crafted.

The recipient thereafter become the "wielder" of that spell on their turn and can use it with their own attack/action rolls.

Many soldiers tell stories of nearly dying before being saved by a Battle Smith and a steel defender.

entries: Artificers are the practical technicians of the magical world. Unlike wizards or sorcerers who pursue more theoretical research, or clerics and druids who are tied to the mandates of their deities or churches, artificers take the practice of magic and tailor it to the needs of the situation. From maintaining complex enhancements along lightning rail lines or on board an elemental airship, to customizing the combat enchantments for a strike team deep behind enemy lines, artificers take the magic that is already at hand and apply it in a more efficient manner, essentially getting more spell for the silver.

entries.name: Arcane Science
entries: In the world of Eberron, arcane magic has been harnessed as a form of science and deployed throughout society. Artificers reflect this development. Their knowledge of magical devices, and their ability to infuse mundane items with magic, allows Eberron's most miraculous projects to continue.

During the Last War, artificers were marshaled on a massive scale. Many lives were saved because of the inventions of brave artificers, but countless lives were also lost because of the mass destruction unleashed by their creations.

entries.name: Seekers of New Lore
entries: Nothing excites an artificer quite like uncovering a new metal or discovering a source of elemental energy. In artificer circles, new inventions and strange discoveries create the most excitement. Artificers who wish to make their mark must innovate, creating something fresh, rather than iterating on familiar designs.

This drive for novelty pushes artificers to become adventurers. Eberron's main travel routes and populated regions have long since been explored. Thus, artificers seek the frontiers of civilization in hopes of making the next great discovery in arcane research.

entries.name: Creating an Artificer
entries: An artificer is the preeminent engineer of magical goods and supplies. Consider what drives your artificer to study and experiment. Is if for fame? For the sake of their knowledge? Proof of concept? Is it under the belief they can make a difference? Or is it really about money?

Think about what your artificer is more focused on. In addition to their main interest a within creation, there will be latitude for most to do other things, but the different schools are better at a certain abilities.

entries.name: Artificers in Other Worlds
entries: Eberron is the world most associated with artificers, yet the class can be found throughout the D&D multiverse. In the Forgotten Realms, for example, the island of Lantan is home to many artificers, and in the world of Dragonlance, tinker gnomes are often members of this class. The strange technologies in the Barrier Peaks of the World of Greyhawk have inspired some folk to walk the path of the artificer, and in Mystara, various nations employ artificers to keep airships and other wondrous devices operational. In the City of Sigil, artificers share discoveries from throughout the cosmos, and one in particular—the gnome inventor Vi—has run a multiverse-spanning business from there since leaving the world of her birth, Eberron. In the world-city Ravnica, the Izzet League trains numerous artificers, the destructiveness of whom is unparalleled in other worlds—except, perhaps, by the tinker gnomes of Krynn.

On a hit, the target takes {@dice 4d6} psychic damage, and the next attack roll and any perception ability checks made by this target before the end of your next turn is at disadvantage, as the target's senses are a riot of confusing thoughts.
{@b Reversible}: {@spell Guiding Bolt|phb}

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledice 4d6|1-9|1d6} for each slot level above 1st.

entries.name: Diminish Ability
entries: You touch a creature and bestow upon it a magical enhancement. Choose one of the following effects; the target gains that effect until the spell ends.

entries.name: Butterfly's Endurance
entries: The target has disadvantage on Constitution checks. It also loses {@dice 2d4} Maximum hit points.

entries.name: Infant's Strength
entries: The target has disadvantage on Strength checks, and his or her carrying capacity is halved.

entries.name: Bull's Grace
entries: The target has disadvantage on Dexterity checks. It takes double damage from falling.

entries.name: Lepor's Splendor
entries: The target has disadvantage on Charisma checks.

entries.name: Chicken's Cunning
entries: The target has disadvantage on Intelligence checks.

entries.name: Donkey's Wisdom
entries: The target has disadvantage on Wisdom checks.
{@b Reversible}: {@spell Enhance Ability|phb}

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 2nd.

entries.name: Dirge Drain

components.m: a red thread not less than 3 inches in length

entries: A whisps of night blue smoke flow out toward a creature within range, forming intangible bands of dark energy looping between you and the target. Make a ranged spell attack against that creature. On a hit, a dark pulse of nightblue energy slams into the target dealing {@dice 1d10} psychic damage, and on each of your turns for the duration, you can use your action to deal 1d10 psychic damage to the target automatically. The spell ends if you use your action to do anything else. The spell also ends if the target is ever outside the spell's range, or has total cover from you.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the initial damage increases by {@scaledice 1d10|1-9|1d12} for each slot level above 1st.

entries.name: Cursed Tablet
entries: You inscribe your victim's name on a lead tablet, invoke the spirits of the dead, and place the tablet in an occupied tomb.

Each midnight thereafter, your victim must succeed at a Wisdom saving throw. Failure means the target suffers horrifying nightmares of its own death. When the target wakes up, it will have taken a level of exhaustion that cannot be removed until the target gets an undisturbed night's rest. The creature will also takes {@dice 1d4} psychic damage to MAX hp. The levels of exhaustion are cumulative. If the target succeeds on the saving throw, he is unaffected that night.

If your target succeeds at three saving throws in a row, the curse is broken and the spell ends. If the curse tablet, which radiates both magic and evil, is found and destroyed, this also breaks the curse, but it will inflict {@dice 1d10}/per level of target's exhaustion of psychic damage to the target as well. Because the curse is laid upon the tablet and not directly on the target, a remove curse spell will not end the curse if cast upon the target creature, but does if cast upon the tablet. A remove Curse will, however, give the target advantage on the next night's saving throw.
The spell can also be ended by greater restoration, heal, or wish.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the spell lasts an additional two days per spell slot above 3rd level.

entries.name: Tasha's Piteous Lamantation

components.m: A verse of Vogathan Poetry or Salt Water & a bit of Onion

entries: A creature of your choice that you can see within range perceives everything as devastatingly sorrowful and drops to the floor sobbing, and crying. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or fall {@condition prone}, becoming incapacitated and unable to stand up for the duration. A creature with an Intelligence score of 4 or less, or constructs are not affected.

At the end of each of its turns, and each time it takes damage, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. The target has advantage on the saving throw if it's triggered by damage or given the help action. On a success, the spell ends.
{@b Reversible}: {@spell Tasha's Hideous Laughter|phb}

entries.name: Killing Jar

components.m: a vial a drop of honey and drop of poison or acid.

entries: You curse a creature within range against attack. Until the spell ends, all creatures within the 30 ft. range who attempts to target another creature for an attack must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creatures instead target the cursed creature or may choose to forfeit their attack and bonus action(s). This spell doesn't protect creatures around the cursed creature even if the Area of Effect would include the attacker/caster or its allies.
If the cursed creature heals or gives the help action to a creature, that creature no longer is compelled to attack the cursed creature.
{@b Reversible}: {@spell sanctuary|phb}

entries.name: Emnity/Regret

components.m: a small amount of soured milk a bit of broken bridge.

entries: The spell has two phases
{@b Phase one}:

items: Duration (1 round per Creature's CR/Level)

The target is moved to hatred and bitter enmity against you (and those with you), and it has disadvantage on all Charisma-based skill checks/saves. On the roll of 5 or less the creature (if prone to violence) will attack you. Another creature might seek retribution in other ways (at the DM's discretion). The targeted creature is allowed to roll a Wisdom or Charisma save (their choice) against attacking. If they fail, the attack hostilities continue.

entries: {@b Phase two}:

items: At the end of the first stage spell, the targeted creature is aware that it was given feelings of hatred and enmity towards you and your fellow party members, but not from where. The creature; if good - will likely seek to make amends; if evil - may seek to kill you anyway, may seek to align with you, or just interrogate the party about what just happened.

entries: {@b Reversible}: {@spell Friends|phb}

entries.name: Distraction
entries: One creature you can see must make a Wisdom saving throw or lose 1 attack in its attack actions. Being too preoccupied with its own thoughts or too distracted by shiny things to notice any movement, sound, or smell around them. Creatures with an Intelligence of 3 or less or that are immune to being charmed are unaffected by this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: The number of people you can affect increases to 3 when you reach 5th level, 6 when you reach 5th level, and 12 when you reach 17th level.

entries.name: Enervating Ennui
entries: Choose one creature that you can see within range. The target is struck with ennui. Creatures that can't be charmed are immune to this spell. The target creature loses all its movement and has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and attack rolls. While the target is affected by this spell, other creatures have advantage on attack rolls against it. As an action, the creature makes a Wisdom saving throw to regain control of itself. On a successful save, the spell ends.

entries.name: Intensify Sensation
entries: You touch a creature, who must make a wisdom saving throw if unwilling. The creature will perceive sensations significantly more intensely. Physical and emotional sensations as being unbelievably powerful, for good or bad. A creature hit while under the influence of this spell makes a Constitution saving throw or is rendered incapacitated until the end of their next action
Spells designed to create an emotion or physical sensation have twice the duration as normal and the creature saves against them at disadvantage. Creatures may save again at the start of each round.

entries.name: Kiss of Torment
entries: You must touch a creature's bare flesh, either literally kissing the creature or brushing it with your fingertips. That creature may make a Constitution saving throw. On a success, the spell ends. On a failure, the creature takes {@dice 4d6} psychic damage and is in so much pain that it is incapacitated for the duration. It may make a new saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending that effect on a success. However, each round that the creature remains incapacitated, it takes an additional 2d6 psychic damage.

entries.name: Major Curse
entries: You touch a creature, and it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become cursed for the duration of the spell. When you cast this spell, choose one feature of the curse from the following options:

items: Choose one ability score. That ability is reduced by 10 (not to be less than 3).
The creature had disadvantage on all attack, damage, and saving throws.
The creature is paralyzed for the duration of the spell.
All attacks and spells deal an additional {@dice 1d12} necrotic damage to the target.

The creature begins to slowly die. After every long rest, it takes {@dice 1d10} damage of a type of your choice to and its MAX HP total is reduced by 1 point. MAX HP total is restored to normal only after this curse is lifted.

{@b Allergy}: Whenever the creature encounters a particular substance, it becomes incredibly nauseated. It must make a Constitution saving throw or become incapacitated for 2d6 rounds due to vomiting and dry heaves and be {@condition poisoned} for 10 minutes.
{@b Incompetence}: The creature loses their proficiency with a skill, tool, or specific weapon (ie. longsword).

entries: A remove curse ends the chosen effect. At the DM's option, you may choose an alternative curse effect, but it should be no more powerful than those described above. The DM has final say on the curse's effect.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: If you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level, the duration is up to 1 hour. 8th level, the duration is up to 24 hours. If you use a 9th-level spell slot, the spell lasts until it is dispelled or the curse is removedby {@spell remove curse|phb}. Using a spell slot of 7th level or higher grants doesn't require use of concentration.

entries.name: Nerve Dance

components.m: a six-inch strand of red spider silk and a torch

entries: You hold your hand out and three glowing red streamers shoot out. Each of these streamers wraps around a target of your choice within range, using your spell attack modifier to hit.

On a hit, they wrap around a target, grappling it (escape DC equal to your spell save DC), and must make a Wisdom saving throw. The creature takes {@dice 6d6} psychic damage and is incapacitated due to incredible pain for the spells duration if they fail a dexterity save, on a successful save the targets take half as much damage and is incapacitated until then end of thier next round.
A creature saves at the end of each of its round to end the magical {@condition incapacited} condition.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledice 1d6 + 10|1-9|1d6} for each slot level above 1st.

entries.name: Aura of Lies
entries: You create a magical aura that grants advantage with deception/persuasion when attempting to tell at lie intentionally. If cast upon an unwililng/unknowing target until the spell ends, that creatures makes a Charisma saving throw, if successful they make make an intelligence saving throw to be aware of the spell's nature or else believe they are under the effects of a Zone of Truth.

When a creature with Aura of Lies upon it enters a zone of truth, they can lie intentionally while in a Zone of Truth without the caster of Zone of Truth being magically alerted. Furthermore attempts to be completely honest within a Zone of Truth by a creature with the Aura of Lies upon it will, to that creature, sound like their intended words, but to the listeners their statement will be the opposite of that intented statement.
(eg. I have proudly returned triumph - would come out as I failed

entries.name: Rending
entries: This spell creates a single break or tear in an object you touch -- broken chain links, break a key, put a ragged tear in a cloak, or rupture a wineskin. The break or tear is no larger than 1 foot in any dimension.
Per casting upon on an item it does:

items: {@b Structure}: Deals 1pts of force damage at 1st level, 2pts at 5th level, 4pts at 11th level, 8pts 17th level.
{@b Weapon} (normal): the weapon suffers a permanent -1 to hit and damage (and can no longer perform critical hits).
{@b Armor} (normal): armor is reduced by 1 AC permanently.
{@b +x Magic Weapon/Armor}: Removes the magical attribute to bypass damage resistance and reduces its effective bonus by 1 each time.
{@b Charged Magical item}: Reduces the item by 1 charge.
{@b other Magic Items}: (excluding Artifacts) the item loses a random feature or ability with each casting upon it for one minute.

entries: A {@spell dispel magic|phb} or {@spell Mending|phb} will reverse one step of damange instances of Rending being cast.
An item is destroy when:

items: {@b Structure}: rendered to 0 HP
{@b Weapon} (normal): weapon is reduced to being able to only deal 1pt of damage.
{@b Armor} (normal): armor is reduced to 0 ac of protection.
{@b Charged Magical item}: When cast upon it when the item has 0 charges.
{@b +x Magic Weapon/Armor}: cannot be destroyed, just effectively negated.

entries.name: Phantom Stash

components.m: spider and a bit of webbing frozen in amber

entries: This ritual can be used by any Phantom Blade Rogue to store a held object in their personal extradimensional space. The ritual version takes 1 minute to perform. The object must remain held for the entire duration or the spell fails. Your extradimensional space can hold any number of objects, but its maximum capacity is equal to 2 lbs per character level. If you attempt to cast this spell with an object that would cause you to exceed this weight limit, the spell fails. If the spell succeeds the object is stored safely within your extradimensional space. If you are attuned to the object, you remain attuned to it even if it is stored in your extradimensional space.

entries.name: Phantom Recall
entries: Select one object stored within your personal extradimensional storage space. This object is summoned to your hand. If you have no hands free, this cantrip fails. The object is removed from your extradimensional storage space once it appears in your hand.

entries.name: Phantom Blade

components.m: a weapon held within your extradimensional storage space.

entries: As an action, you can make a melee spell attack against any target.

Select an object from within your personal extradimensional space to use as the weapon for this attack. That object is momentarily materialized hurling towards the target of the spell - dealing damage commensurate with the archetype's object's damage.

If you hit your target with this attack, the target is subject to any magical enhancements and properties of the selected weapon as if the attack was wielded, though no 'activation'/keyword abilities can be utilized in the flicker of its existence out of the dimensional pocket.
This spell is subject to augmentations which will amend or replace spell features.
Use the object/weapon's range in determining ranges. Ammunition can not be evoked by the spell.

spell.name: Steel Defender
entries: By 3rd level, your tinkering has borne you a faithful companion, a {@creature steel defender|MMMxArtificer}. It is friendly to you and your companions, and it obeys your commands. See this creature's game statistics in the steel defender stat block. You determine the creature's appearance and whether it has two legs or four; your choice has no effect on its game statistics.

In combat, the steel defender shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but the only action it takes on its turn is the {@action Dodge} action, unless you take a bonus action on your turn to command it to take one of the actions in its stat block or the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Search} action.

If the {@spell mending} spell is cast on it, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points. If it has died within the last hour, you can use your smith's tools as an action to revive it, provided you are within 5 feet of it and you expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher. The steel defender returns to life after 1 minute with all its hit points restored.
At the end of a long rest, you can create a new steel defender if you have your smith's tools with you. If you already have a steel defender from this feature, the first one immediately perishes.
